dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High angle of the steam train travelling through a wide river valley. The stack belching smoke against the Russia sky. 2   INT. SECOND CLASS CARRIAGE. COUNTRY SIDE. DAY. Leo Tolstoy (80), sits writing on his lapboard. He is qui simply the greatest living writer in the world. His devotion to pacifism, his rejection of the trappings of Orthodoxy in favor of a simple Christian lifestyle convin many to regard him as a living saint. With him are his mu younger wife, the COUNTESS SOFYA, favorite daughter SASHA and his personal physician DUSHAN MAKOVITSKY. Sasha and Dushan write in their diaries. Sofya looks from one to th next a little impatient. The train begins to slow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are we slowing down? No one responds. Slower. Slower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're stopping. Why are we stopping?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, mother.    No idea. Tolstoy look up from his work, asks a passing conductor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, why has the train stopped?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the crowd, ma'm, the people. They're blocking the track. In the distance we can here voices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long live Tolstoy! Long live the old warrior!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if they block the track, the train can't go...YOU HAVE TO MAKE THEM MOVE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conductor shrugs, walks away. She goes to the window investigate. A crowd of a hundred peasants, students surround the engine, block the track. They carry a huge cloth banner honoring Tolstoy. We can hear voices chantin "Tolstoy. Tolstoy. Tolstoy", voices crying "You are the truth." "You are the hope of the Russian people."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, they won't move. We are gonna die here. Leo, Leo, go and say something to them. It's the only way we are gonna get out of here. The chanting grows in intensity. Tolstoy gets to his feet walks to the window, shows himself to the crowd. A great shout goes up. Tolstoy lifts his hand for silence. Gradually, it comes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have seen your banner. And IВґve heard what you say. You think IВґm the hope of Russia, do you? Well, thatВґs not true. You are the hope of Russia. The hope of all the world. You say, you want a new way to live? Well, you are not gonna find it making a fuss over me. So, I suggest that you get on with your work and let a poor old men get on with his. The cries begin. "Clear the tracks. Let them pass. Let th go." Tolstoy closes the door and waves to the crowd as th train pulls away. 3   EXT. COUNTRYSIDE. DAY. On the chanting crowd now as the train pulls away. We focus on a handsome young man, a little stiff maybe, a little intellectual. This is VALENTIN FEDOROVITCH BULGAKOV. He can't contain his enthusiasm. Over the noise of the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know who that is? That is the greatest man in the world. The train pulls away into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. DAWN.
dialogues.text: The ancestral home of the Tolstoy family in the first budding of spring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muzhiks (peasants) gather wood, carry water to the house. cart arrives loaded down with mail bags. 5    INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. SOFYA'S BEDROOM. DAY. A handsome room, walls covered with generations of family photographs. Religious icons are given pride of place, a testament, not to piety, but to an ingrained social conservatism, a certain position in the world. Countess Sofya mumbles her morning prayers before a make shift altar. Wiping away tears, she leaves the room. 5A   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. ENTRY/STAIR. DAY. Sofya walks down the stairs and through the entry passed old servant asleep in a chair. She continues to the basement. 6    INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. TOLSTOY'S BEDROOM/STUDY. DAY. Tolstoy has moved himself out of the refined upper floors into a simple vaulted room he uses as both bedroom and study. The walls are bare except for a portrait of his daughter. The furniture is simple, some of it hand made: small bed against the wall, a little writing desk in one corner stacked with books, littered with papers, more mai opened and unopened. Pairs of rude homemade shoes line a work bench. Tolstoy sleeps in his bed. Though it's late March and still cold, the window is open. Sofya closes it. She stands very still, watching Tolstoy sleep. Sitting on the bed, she gently touches his hand, whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling. She lies next to him, something girlish, hopeful in her face, as if waiting for him to wake up and adore her, but he sleeps on. She carefully takes his arm, positions it under her neck, and rolling toward him, wraps it around her. The image of love's intimacy, of wedded bliss. His hand slips off her shoulder, once, twice. She moves awkwardly to replace it. He moves a little toward her. Sh kisses his neck, his cheek. We don't know if he's awake, but even this shadow of intimacy penetrates her soul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A handsome study in the Moscow townhouse of VLADIMIR GRIGOREVICH CHERTKOV, Tolstoy's most articulate and dedicated disciple. He's interviewing Tolstoy's newly appointed secretary, VALENTIN BULGAKOV, the young man we met near the train, who, at the mention of sex, blushes a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But sex... You are twenty three. Not an easy age for abstinence, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tolstoy does not approve of sexual relations. I know this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He despises them, in fact... Chertkov reaches for a small tin of moustache wax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to belabor the point, but I arranged for a manservant last year who proceeded to ruin two housemaids just like that. He was very upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This would not be a problem. I'm celibate. I'm also a strict vegetarian. Chertkov nods his approval, begins to worry his moustache

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I've heard many good things about you. I've even read what you`ve written. So has he. Valentin's face flushes with pride. Chertkov steals a glance at his reflection in the glass bookcase. One side his moustache droops a little. He tugs awkwardly at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear boy, if you were to become Tolstoy's private secretary, you would be given a great gift. You'll be with him every day, eat together, walk in the forest by his side. It's difficult to contain himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me, since becoming a Tolstoyan, I have become so eager to learn, so comitted to discussing ideas, improving my very soul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Well, we have a lot to do if we are to get his work to the people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We? They both laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, we. If we can encourage the spread of passive resistance...just think of it Valentin   thousands of ordinary Russians casting off centuries of spiritual and political oppression-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the name of truth and freedom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truth and freedom, yes but still, my boy, there are so many enemies-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enemies? Chertkov walks to the window, signals Valentin to follow him. He points to TWO MEN IN PLAINCLOTHES standing in the street below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Czar's police...You'll be followed when you leave here...and the church will stop at nothing to bring him back into the fold. His children can't be trusted... only Sasha... and then of course there is the Countess... (beat) Well, one doesn't like to come between married people whatever the circumstances, but her dogged attachment to private property, her public criticism of our movement...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHERTKOV (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) The point is, he needs a man of your intellectual gifts around him. Someone who can help him with the new work. Someone who understands his goals. Chertkov returns to the desk. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And although they've allowed me to return to Russia, I can't see him. They keep me under house arrest... They might as well keep me in a cage. Clearly upset, Chertkov pauses to get control of himself. He picks up a package, hands it to Valentin. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, I need you to put these letters directly into his hands. One can't be sure what gets through to him. Valentin looks at him, quizzical. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofya Andreyevna does not respect his privacy. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wouldn't open his private correspondence... Chertkov raises an eyebrow. An ominous silence. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have another task for you, my dear. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll keep a diary for me. He hands Valentin a notebook. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to know everything that goes on at Yasnaya Polyana. Let me know who visits the house, any talk of the copyright to his work, any contact with the church, what letters come and go. (beat) Anything Sofya Andreyevna says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything? CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's very, very dangerous. 9    EXT. MOSCOW. DOORWAY/STREET. EVENING. Chertkov kisses Valentin delicately on both cheeks and ushers him into the dying light. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Godspeed, my boy. Valentin makes his way to the droshky that awaits him. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And remember what I said. He turns back to the dark figure in the doorway. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Write everything down! Go! 10   EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. GROUNDS. MORNING. SOFYA. Black and white film of her being handed the newspapers at the step. She looks up at the camera, irritated by its presence. CUTTING OUT TO COLOR we see a cinematographer on the lawn cranking away at his camera. She goes into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Tolstoy, awake and dressed, sits on his bed, pen in hand, writing in his diary. Dushan sits next to him, taki his pulse. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing's working... Hand me my other boot, my friend, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me finish. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter. If my heart had stopped beating, I'd still go riding today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your pulse is my responsibility... (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DUSHAN (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and if you must ride, I insist you wear a coat. Even the sun is cold today. He puts Tolstoy's arm down and hands him his riding boot. Sofya comes ranting into the room carrying several Russia and international dailies. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is impossible! It really is! These people are parasites! Look... (reading) "Countess Tolstoy has become estranged from her husband. They barely speak." She throws the paper on the floor. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know who spreads all this rubbish.... She opens another paper, a French daily. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'est la meme en France. They gossip about us in Paris... "They do not share a similar view of either religion or politics." Incroyable! TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Peut-etre. You think that's inaccurate? SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's none of the world's business. She looks at Dushan who is transcribing every word into h diary. He does it with all the master's conversations. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Don't do that. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Dushan Petrovich, you're scribbling again? Tolstoy moves with energy and purpose toward the door. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling, where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Riding with Sasha. Don't expect us for lunch. Something strikes him. He walks to his desk, picks up his pen and quickly writes a sentence on a scrap of paper. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leovochka, why do you insist on dressing like that. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like the man who looks after the sheep. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not meant to offend you. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it does offend me, because it offends reason. You're a Count, for God's sake. He puts his pen down, goes to her, kisses her gently on t forehead and leaves the room. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh darling, I have something else to say. TOLSTOY (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt it not, my dear. DUSHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's forgotten his coat. He runs after him, tripping over the long fur garment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Count Tolstoy, you've forgotten your coat. Meanwhile Sofya notices a photographic portrait of Chertk on the wall. She takes it down and tosses it in the corner. 12   EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. GROUNDS. DAY. As Tolstoy appears on the porch, we hear the WHIR of cameras. A crowd of photographers, film cameramen, journalists, and disciples try to catch a glimpse of the master. Dushan steps in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DUSHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him walk. Let him walk. JOURNALIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Count Tolstoy, you're no doubt distressed by the Czar's treatment of your secretary Nikolai Gusev ? TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These people are bandits. DUSHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, let him walk. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come into my house and arrest a man whose only crime is to express a view of life saner than that which prevails. JOURNALIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Gusev is innocent? TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) Of course, I'm the guilty one. I reject the Orthodox church. I condemn the established order and I make no secret of it. A young peasant shouts from the crowd. PEASANT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God bless you, Tolstoy. Thank you. DUSHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him walk. Let him walk. (to Tolstoy) But you don't banish these people very much to your credit...I wish I had your largeness of spirit. A photographer's flash goes off. An old Muzhik touches Tolstoy's sleeve, as if expecting a miracle. Sasha, her father's soulmate, leads two horses toward the her mount and her father's black gelding, Delire. SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sasha!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ride this morning? A small crowd collects to watch father and daughter embrace, kiss. A WIDE SHOT of the riders- cutting around we are 13   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. ENTRY/STAIR. CONTINUOUS. Sofya watches her husband and daughter ride away.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RIVER VALLEY. DAY
dialogues.text: A steam train snakes through a broad valley. 15   INT. TRAIN CARRIAGE. DAY. Valentin in his buttoned up suit looks a little out of place in the overcrowded third class carriage. He writes the diary given him by Chertkov. He glances up to see, on the bench across, a young mother taking out her breast to nurse her baby. He blushes, doesn't know where to look. A old peasant catches his eye, winks at him, laughs. 16   EXT. TELYATINKI. DUSK. Seven miles from Tolstoy's estate, this is Telyatinki, a communal center created by Chertkov dedicated to the stud and practice of Tolstoyism. SERGEYENKO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Telyatinki was created by Vladimir Grigorevich as a center for the movement. Just last week we had a visitor from India. We talked to the group about the healing properties of cobra venum. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, goodness..It's a beautiful day. SERGEYENKO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but we will pay for it. Sergeyenko, Chertkov's joyless secretary, and Valentin stand on a second storey porch looking out across the central lawn where a number of young Tolstoyans tend the garden, work to put up a chicken coop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SERGEYENKO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The meeting room is behind us. This is the tool shed. The dormitory ahead. He points out a larger building across the way. 17   INT. TELYATINKI. SLEEPING AREA. NIGHT. They enter the building. SERGEYENKO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Telyatinki is a place of freedom. Nothing is forbidden here. Except everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Each man is alone with his conscience and his God. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kitchen is below. You'll be expected to assist with meals at least twice a week ...and to give a hand in the garden. We're all equals here, you know...as Tolstoy teaches us. They start up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are expected at Yasnaya Polyana in the morning, first thing. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I look forward to it. SERGEYENKO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... you're lucky....We're all envious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small, sparse, perfect for the novice ascetic.   Valentin nods his approval. SERGEYENKO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vladimir Grigorevich is anxious that you begin your reports as soon as possible. You have the notebook he gave you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. SERGEYENKO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You understand we must keep the existence of the diary a secret. Valentin smiles. SERGEYENKO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just that...secrecy doesn't seem to me the essence of Tolstoy's thought. SERGEYENKO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you'll admit, you're no expert. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I...I'll see you in the morning. SERGEYENKO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we're spared. Sergeyenko leaves Valentin to his bare, little room. 19   EXT. TELYATINKI COMPOUND. MORNING. The sun rising. Already, disciples are at work the garden 20   INT. TELYATINKI. VALENTIN'S ROOM. MORNING. Valentin sleeps in his tiny room. A knock on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in. A lovely girl at his door. She's tall, twenties, high che bones, short blonde hair. This is MASHA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've brought you a glass of tea. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very kind of you. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your first day. Enjoy it. She sits on the bed. He's a little taken aback, not used this degree of familiarity. It makes no impression on Masha. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You met Sergeyenko? VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last night. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ad what do you think? VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seems very sincere. Masha hands him his tea. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Why are you laughing? MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say that again. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said he seems very... Why? MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what you think? VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just arrived...What's your name? MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Masha. But you should still say what you think. Not just about him. We all should. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for the tea. Their eyes meet, hold. Valentin's discomfort increases. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow you can make your own. She walks to the door, turns to see him still watching he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a sorry old tight-assed stick in the mud...but yes, he's sincere. 21   EXT. ROAD TO YASNAYA POLYANA.   DAY. A modest horse drawn cart. Valentin sits beside the drive contemplates the birch trees that line the road, the long shadows they cast. Above, crows make lazy circles in the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valentin stands in the entry way, waiting.   He looks los VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello...hello... VOICE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the new secretary. He looks up to see Sasha examining him from the landing above. SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa's out. You can wait in the library. Ivan will show you up. She disappears. He hears a door close. He notices a surly house servant, IVAN, who, inexplicably, leads a goat through the house. He points upstairs and walks away. 24   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. LIBRARY. DAY. Alone now among Tolstoy's books, Valentin makes his way slowly to a writing table, the holy of holies, on which W and Peace and Anna Karenina were written. He runs his han along the old wood top. Emboldened by a backward glance, sits in Tolstoy's chair. Before him are stacks of letters pens and pencils, a pot of India ink. There's a notebook lying open. He leans forward to read it. A noise in the hall stops him. Tolstoy enters from the dining room, red cheeked, beard dripping wet, the energy of a man ten years younger than is. Valentin stands. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you're here. So glad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tromps across the room, kisses the boy enthusiasticall on both cheeks. Valentin is overcome by the great man's warmth. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm... I'm... Here is- Valentin interrupts himself with a sneeze. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God bless you. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.     Sometimes I... Valentin pulls out a letter of introduction. Tolstoy take it out and puts it down without a glance. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vladimir Grigorevich has already written about you at length. I need your help badly. The manifesto against the government is hard work. They commit their idiotic abuses faster than I can catalogue them...and the new book... VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He told me about it...It's very exciting. Tolstoy nods. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've become convinced that all the world's religions have a single organizing principle. Can you guess what it is? Love! Love! Simple... Now, I want to talk about you. How are you? How was your journey? Come, sit down. Tolstoy sits on the old sofa. Valentin follows suit. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I was born on this sofa... Valentin gets right back up. Tolstoy laughs, pats the sof TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit. Sit. Valentin sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myself, my brother, my children, at least five or six of them, right here. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I've read your essays. How`s your work progressing? Valentin looks into the great man's kind old face. He tri to speak but he's overcome with emotion and begins to wee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My boy, what is it? (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I upset you in some way. Was it the sofa? It's only a sofa. Valentin shakes his head, smiling through his tears. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very happy. You are very kind. I'm no one and you are... you are Leo Tolstoy and you ask me about my work. Tolstoy takes Valentin's hand, sits him back on sofa. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You rest for a moment and I'll fetch you a glass of tea. Rest, because there's work for both of us together. He smiles and goes, leaving Valentin to contemplate his fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofya, Sasha, Valentin, ANDREY, Tolstoy's son, and Tolsto all clustered around a table taking tea. Dushan stands ne the group fiddling with a gramophone that sits on a small table. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These people have nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DUSHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It really is the most extraordinary thing. Absolutely ignoring him. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not for lack of land that the muzhiks live in poverty. They have no will power and they drink too much. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not suggesting they be given land. Private property is the root of the problem... We should be giving ours away. ANDREY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it to whom? SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all ridiculous. You think that poverty makes the peasants somehow morally superior. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe that wealth corrupts us all, yes I do. A pause.   Valentin fills the silence. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a keystone of the movement. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I know all about the movement. A pause. Valentin notices that people from the front lawn have moved up to watch all this. Life in the fishbowl, th Tolstoys seem neither to notice nor care. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the peasants had money, they wouldn't surround themselves, as we do, with footmen costing ten rubles a month. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, they'd spend it on drink and whores. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valentin Fedorovich, do you think fifty years from now, people will eat while grown men walk around and wait on them hand and foot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valentin doesn't know what to say. A giggle from Dushan. DUSHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's good...that's good. Dushan, having sat at table, tries surreptitiously to get down Tolstoy's words in the diary he holds below the tabl Sofya flushes with anger. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think...(sneeze) SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop scribbling! (points to her husband) You all think he's Christ, don't you? He thinks he's Christ. There is an awkward pause. DUSHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flustered) I'm not...I don't believe Leo Nikolayevich is Christ. Christ is Christ but... SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what? DUSHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe he's one of the prophets. God speaks through him. I recognize the cadence in his voice. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is unbearable. No wonder I feel lonely. I'm surrounded by morrons. SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama, you're being ridiculous. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I? I sit here and listen to this talk of love and God and equality, knowing full well that Count Generosity here is fully prepared to give away everything we have. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exhausted) You keep going on like that...Why do you think we should profit from the work IВґm doing which is only meant for the sake of the people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to see Dushan scribbling again. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: STOP IT
dialogues.text: Valentin glances at Sasha, uncomfortable at these outbursts. A long pause. Dushan tries to relieve the tension. DUSHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In defense of my gift, let me demonstrate. It's quite remarkable, really. He gets up, places a record on the gramophone, needle on the record. What comes forth is not music, but Tolstoy's voice. It is a recording of a recent speech against capital punishment. His voice booms, tinny and distorted. Dushan walks to the machine, stares at it in awe. Valentin is completely caught up in the technology. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your voice. It's wonderful. They all listen for a moment, look to Tolstoy for a response. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's tiresome. Another remarkable invention will supercede it. Valentin blushes and looks at the table. Dushan tries to hide his disappointment. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please excuse me. Tolstoy rises, leaves the table, walks out onto the lawn. Dushan gets up quickly, bumping the table as he goes. Tea spills. Valentin moves to wipe it up, sneezes, a barrage irritable blessings. DUSHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo Nikolayevich is something of a Luddite, I fear. Sofya crosses to the machine, removes the record from the gramophone, replaces it with another Dushan has brought. Suddenly, the air is filled with   the final duet from Mozart's Il Nozze di Figaro. She   returns to her place. There is a long moment where all   take in the sublimity it. Tolstoy walks slowly back to   the table. He stands completely still. Tears fill his   eyes and roll down his cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thatВґs better. ThatВґs nice. Very nice indeed. Sofya crosses to her husband, wipes the tears off his fac Valentin watches as they embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do your parents often speak to each other so...bluntly? 29   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. LIBRARY. EVENING. Across from Tolstoy's writing desk is Sasha's world, a makeshift office lined with more bookcases where she does her work, sending cables, editing manuscripts, answering endless stacks of mail. Valentin sits near her, learning the ropes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother doesn't understand my father's goals, not since his work as a novelist became secondary.    His commitment to the spiritual life offends her. They've fought about it for years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure she means well. Sasha just looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father is the greatest writer in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean to say, I feel privileged to be here. It's an... honor. Valentin feels himself slip further into mundanity. Sasha goes back to her letter.   Valentin SNEEZES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God Bless You. They read together for a moment.   He sneezes again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God bless you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Sometimes I sneeze when I'm nervous. She regards him like an animal in the zoo. Ivan appears a the door. SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? IVAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ItВґs a note, for him. He nods toward Valentin. SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, give it to him then. Valentin reads the note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ItВґs from your mother. She wants to see me. As Valentin goes, SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is looking for allies. Pay attention. This is war. 30   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. SITTING ROOM. NIGHT. Sofya is settled on a divan in a small room off the dinin room. Valentin sits beside her holding a glass of tea. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see a fine young man before me. Clear eyes. Nice features, rather handsome in a peculiar way. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Countess...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me Sofya Andreyevna. We don't stand on formality here, as you may have observed. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Many young men ruin their looks by loose living. You're a real Tolstoyan, I can tell! VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I admire your husband immensely. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's excellent. He likes that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His ideas are beautiful...social justice...the idea...Don't you think? Sofya drains her tea cup, signals for more. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's very grateful for the help you've been giving him. He told me so himself. I think it surprises him that a young man would be so diligent. When he was your age, he was whoring in the Caucasus. Valentin's eyes are wide. She nods. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wrote it all down. He even gave me a copy, so I could read all the details... VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've read War and Peace? VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Many times... twice. Sofya smiles at his honesty. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he was writing it, long before Chertkov created that monstrosity at Telyatinki, before all this "new religion" and revolutionary nonsense... (beat) What do you think of Chertkov, by the way? VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's given me an extraordinary opportunity. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you see what a fool he is, a self-serving puritanical idiot. I have to say, it's been extremely pleasant since they've locked him in his house. Sofya smiles. Valentin is nonplussed by her directness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When my husband was writing it, in the mid-sixties, he'd bring me pages to re-copy everyday. I was the only one who could read his handwriting. I could read his intentions, too. Afternoons, we'd drink tea and discuss changes. "Natasha wouldn't say that to Prince Andrey," or "Pierre's too simple here. He's not stupid." She smiles at the memory. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I don't count anymore. Silence. She sips her tea. She glances out the door to se Sasha hovering nearby. Listening? Sasha walks away. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must help me, Valentin Fedorovich. I want only what is best for my husband and my family. I could tolerate the situation if it only concerned me What I can not do is sit back while they steal my children's inheritance. Do you know I was the only person. I could understand his intention. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe anyone wants to do that. Sofya gives him a condescending smile. She produces a package from the table beside her, hands it to him. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a little gift for you He opens it, extracts a small leather bound book. He star at it. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a diary. (beat) Everyone should always keep a diary. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a very popular activity around your husband. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're teasing me, but I trust you'll write the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That may not be so easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense. You've been listening to your friends at Telyatinki... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Write what you see. That's always the place to begin. (slowly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What. You. See. Valentin fingers the package, stifles a sneeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More tea?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TELYATINKI COMPOUND. DAY
dialogues.text: Valentin rides into the compound. A number of the discipl are outside working. There is the ringing of metal on wood. He looks for the source. As the way clears a little he sees Masha chopping away with an axe. He stops his hor to watch her. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're finished for the day? VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't need me this afternoon. He gets down off his horse. Masha continues to chop. He picks up an axe, holds it awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo Nikolayevich disapproves of women doing physical labor. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you find that reactionary? MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I find it sweet. I find you reactionary. She laughs. Valentin picks up a log, sets it on end and begins to chop. He doesn't do it well. Masha smiles at hi struggle. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He admires you, I believe. What's she saying? MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergeyenko told me. He's miserable about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tolstoy's kind to everyone. The log is stuck to the blade of his axe. He's really struggling now. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you talk about when you're with him? (beat) Why are you blushing? VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We talk about me. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants to know everything about me, my parents, my relations with women, my experience of god - He looks up to see Masha smiling at him. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what relations are these? Valentin blushes, goes back to trying to chopping. Almost immediately the log becomes stuck to the blade of the axe He bangs it, bangs it trying to free it. He glances up to see her still looking at him. He pounds again and again. She stops, reaches for his axe, touching him as she does. She lifts the big axe, log and all, above her head, bringing it down hard. The log splits. She hands the axe him. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a lover before I came here... headmaster of a school where I taught. He was married - happily married. It was difficult. We could make love only at school. This is somehow more than Valentin had bargained for. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At school? MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the gymnasium, after the girls had gone. There were straw mats on the floor. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks away to hide his confusion. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have I upset you? He looks at her. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...I appreciate your frankness MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you disapprove of me. I see it in your eyes. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't. Not at all...I think sexual activity...how men and women combine their physical parts is completely neutral. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to you. You're a prig. Just like Sergeyenko. Why else would they have hired you? VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not fair MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care if it's fair. It's true...neutral...my God... VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going. He puts down the axe. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do as you like. She goes back to chopping. We track in front of him as he walks toward the house. The chopping stops. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valentin Fedorovich. He stops, relieved and turns to face her. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You forgot your horse. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. You know, I think that I... never mind. He hesitates for a moment, then starts toward her. Her ba is to him. She begins to chop again. The color rises in h face as he tries to salvage a little dignity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs the reins and starts again toward the buildings, trips in a ditch, almost falls flat. Red faced, he rights himself. The chopping behind him remains constant. Sergeyenko watches him from the porch.

dialogues.speaker: INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. LIBRARY. DAY
dialogues.text: CLOSE on the CABLE MACHINE.    A message coming through. 32A   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. ENTRY WAY/STAIR. DAY. Sofya walks into the house with another stack of mail. Sasha comes piling down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's papa? Without waiting for the answer, Sasha races past her and out the door

dialogues.speaker: EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. ZASYEKA WOODS. DAY
dialogues.text: Valentin and Tolstoy walk together in the woods. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't write. I was distracted I think...I had a dream last night, about a Tartar girl I knew in the war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A girl who died?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no...A girl I had sexual intercourse with... Sometimes we did it twice a day. Valentin sneezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God bless...I've never forgotten our time together, the position of our bodies, the taste of her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't torture yourself. It was a long time ago. Tolstoy laughs out loud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Torture? You are a virgin, aren't you. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I try to...you know, to... TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be what, a good Tolstoyan? Tolstoy smiles. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, I myself am not a very good Tolstoyan. You should think twice about asking my advice about anything... Torture... (he laughs) VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you alright? TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kalya, her name was...She's an old woman now, white hair, old body like me. She'd hardly remember my name, I suspect. She may even be dead. (beat) Do you think that meant something? VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean that little romance. Was there some meaning to it? VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ItВґs interesting. I think you would say..I mean, IВґve read where you say that the physical body isnВґt real. That itВґs all an illusion. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say lots of things. What do you say? What do you think? VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I...I donВґt know. Leo Nikoleyevich smiles. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I donВґt know, either. He inhales deeply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smell that... VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilac? He looks up as he hears Sasha off screen. "Papa. Papa."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Precisely. It's lilac. The smell's stronger when the sun goes down. He presses Valentin's hand. SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa! TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've enjoyed myself, my boy. (shouting for Sasha)

dialogues.speaker: WE'RE HERE.
dialogues.text: As he starts in the direction of her voice. Sasha appears in the clearing, telegram in hand. SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's free. He's free...He's coming back Smash cut to

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RAILWAY. COUNTRYSIDE. DAY
dialogues.text: A train roars past camera, shaking the world.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. GROUNDS. DAY
dialogues.text: Chertkov climbs down from his droshky. Suddenly, Tolstoy there. Valentin watches them embrace. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear, dear man. Tears run down his old cheeks. They embrace again. SOFYA (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll try again to convince your father to change his will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrey and Sofya stand together at the window, watching t joyful reunion. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To give the copyright as "a gift to humanity."...the reptile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa's not in his right mind. He can't defend himself against these thieves. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My tooth is killing me. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a fine son, darling. None of this make believe chastity and made up religion. I wish all my children had turned out like you. Andrey's finger in his mouth, massages the offending mola ANDREY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man'th responthibility ith to hith family. From her POV, we see the two men walk away together arm i arm, talking animatedly. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chertkov's notions of virtuous behavior are calculated to destroy me. ANDREY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To dethtroy uth all. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is nothing more pathetic than impoverished aristocrats. She walks out of the room. 39   EXT. GROUNDS. YASNAYA POLYANA. DAY. And into the drive to greet Chertkov. He moves immediatel to her, offers her his hand and an unctuous smile. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vladimir Grigorevich, what a surprise. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofya Andreyevna, I'm happy to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valentin watches her match him smile for smile. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm happy to make you happy...always.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ROAD TO TELYATINKI. DAY
dialogues.text: Valentin and Chertkov sit together in the droshky, an awkward silence. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad to have a moment alone with you, Valentin. How do you think you're getting on? VALENTIN (a little nervous)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope my work is pleasing to Leo Nikolayevich. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. He seems satisfied and that's good. The reports I've received from you however... There seems to be some confusion. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You send me never ending commentary on Tolstoy's writing. That's all very interesting but not very useful. I need to know what goes on with Sofya Andreyevna. You must see by now she's committed to undermining her husband's best intentions. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not quite so obvious to me. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because she is duplicitous. You are very bright. Too bright to let her into you. Chertkov fixes the boy with his intense gaze. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You value our work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ideals we share? VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, of course it is. (beat) Do you think the Countess suspects something? VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I think the Countess is very suspicios by nature. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How so? VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I donВґt think she likes you very much. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does she say? VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ItВґs a tone IВґve picked up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We simply want to distribute Tolstoy's work to the widest audience possible. She just has no understanding what it is we are trying to do. ThereВґs nothing in it for any of us but a real chance to increase the worldВґs happiness. He takes Valentin's hand. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can only be of limited help to the master if I don't know what's going on. Any effort she makes to shore up control of the copyright, I must know. The survival of our movement depends on it. Remember who your friends are. What you've come here to do. Chertkov turns away to watch the countryside. Valentin stares straight ahead, his nose twitches slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valentin, in bed, writes in his diary. Closing his eyes, begins to drift off when there is a noise outside his doo VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello... Hello? After a moment, it opens a crack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Masha? She is there. She puts two fingers to her lips and walks toward him. She carries a candle which reveals her short hair, her lovely eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Masha. She says nothing, simply crawls into bed, positions her knees on either side of him. She leans forward and kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Masha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ssshh. She begins to move against him. Their faces touch. She doesn't kiss him, but he can feel her breath. She sits up MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your book. It's true. Valentin still clutches the diary to his chest He puts it aside. Masha, then, pulls her nightdress over head, exposing her small breasts, her flat stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches under the sheets, curls her fingers around hi He flinches at the pleasure of it. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it alright? He can't speak. Only nod. He bites his lip as she slips h into her and begins to rock. The pleasure is too much, an he comes too quickly. She falls forward on him, begins to laugh. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What...what is it? MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really are a virgin. Valentin tenses a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm playing. It's fine. It's wonderful... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold me. He does, as if he'll never release her. 48   EXT. TELYATINKI COMPOUND. MORNING. Activity in the compound. Chairs on the lawn, a banner being erected, a long table being set. Preparations being made. 49   INT. TELYATINKI. VALENTIN'S ROOM. MORNING. Light spills into Valentin's room. He lies with his arms around naked Masha. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wake up, wake up. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am awake. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to ask you something..Say it again. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was wonderful. They both giggle. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you come to a place like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You donВґt follow any of the rules. Masha smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean, why does someone who doesn't follow the rules come to a place like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..it's not about rules.    Not for Tolstoy anyway... A knock at the door startles them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valentin Fedorovich. Valentin is suddenly in a panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? 49A   INT. TELYATINKI. CORRIDOR. DAY. Sergeyenko hovers outside the bedroom door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the moment, I'm indisposed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, well...Leo Nikolayevich is here. He want s to see you. 49B   INT. TELYATINKI. VALENTIN'S ROOM. DAY. Valentin blanches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him... I'll be down at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes..and tell Maria Filipovna we could use another hand in the kitchen. They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I see her I will...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you see her...yes. And if you're going to behave like rabbits, you should go live in the woods. Valentin is up, immediately. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me go out first...give me five minutes... Masha just looks at him. 50   EXT. TELYATINKI COMPOUND. DAY. A Tolstoyan photo op. A delegation of orphans have come t pay their respects to Tolstoy. He sits in a chair beside Chertkov beneath a large banner : "Leo Tolstoy, Friend of the People.". Behind him, the disciples lay out a vegetarian feast on a plank table. Photographers and a cinematographer are strategically positioned to record th event. Each child gives Tolstoy a flower. Chertkov, in turn, han each child a photograph of the Count giving money to the poor. Valentin enters, flushed and blushing. He pauses beside Dushan who records the scene in his diary, tears in his eyes. DUSHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at the love in him, like Jesus..suffering the children...all that... Tolstoy greets a little boy affectionately, rubs his knuckles over the boy's shaved head. A little girl approaches, takes a photograph. He bends forward to kiss her head but she pulls away. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old man is a very ugly thing. Tolstoy sees Valentin, lights up. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear boy. Come and kiss me. Valentin, beet red, goes to him. He is warmly embraced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, who is this? Maria Filipovna. Masha comes to stand beside him. She glances at Valentin but he won't make eye contact with her. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're both looking so well. Life here at Telyatinki obviously agrees with you. Valentin sneezes mightily, moves a little away. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God bless you, boy. What are you nervous about, now? Sit down. Sit down. Valentin takes the chair beside him. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Masha, Valentin tells me you're the great treasure of Telyatinki. He claims you're a very gifted teacher. Sergeyenko lifts an eyebrow "Indeed.". Valentin is in agony. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're happy to have you with us. Tolstoy notices a mosquito on Valentin's cheek. He takes the bug between his big fingers, squeezes until it pops. Chertkov watches in horror, whispers loudly. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing? TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? He motions to the photographers. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've killed a living thing. Chertkov hears a laugh behind him.   It is Masha who has over heard the whole thing. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have something to say? MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's absurd. That's all. Chertkov is taken aback.   Valentin stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you saying? MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry but- It's a mosquito. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive him. He can't help it. He's a better Tolstoyan than I am. She can't help laughing again. Valentin sees the color ri in Chertkov's face. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not the message we want to send. Sasha suddenly appears. She holds a cable in her hand. SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From my mother "Nerves dreadful. Stop. Insomnia. Stop. Pulse 100. Stop. Please come home. 51   INT. TELYATINKI. CHERTKOV'S STUDY. DAY. Chertkov is there. Tolstoy, Valentin and Sasha. SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't give in to her, Papa. It'll never end...I swear to God, that woman has an instinct for knowing when you're just about to enjoy yourself A knock on the door. Valentin opens it. It's Dushan with another cable. Tolstoy gestures for him to read it aloud. DUSHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Sofya Andreyevna. "I beg you. Stop. Unwell. Stop. Hurry back." SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who taught her to use that damned machine? Valentin starts to sneeze, stifles it, starts again, stifles, starts, explodes. Guilty. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps Sasha's right. Encouraging this may not be the best thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a trick, Papa. She'll drain you. You'll be miserable. Tolstoy looks from one to the other, gets up from his chair. SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, let me go with you. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, my dear, I'll go alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on Sofya lying in bed. She looks ravishing in the candle light. In the background, Tolstoy arrives in the bedroom door. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofya. A sly smile on her lips, the tension gone from her face, she seems twenty years younger. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofya, are you ill? She rolls toward him making it clear she's quite naked under the sheets. This is no sick bed. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine...now that you're home. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's no good, you know, all this. You frightened everyone. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I really? I don't believe it. Not you. I'm your little bird. You know the sounds I make. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was some sort of love call? SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It brought you back to me. She reaches out her hand to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come out of the dark... where I can see you. He takes a step toward her, then stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Why? Why, do you do it? We live in the country and you insist on making it an opera house. What's wrong with a little peace now and then? Sofya laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at me. This is who I am. This is what you married. We're older, maybe we're old, but I'm still your little chicken (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're still my big cock. She smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me make you crow. A pause, then a huge laugh comes up from the very center him. He twists his neck, thrusts his head upward, crows like a rooster. He virtually runs to her, embraces her, kisses her. She i a giddy girl in his arms. He breaks the embrace and begin strutting around the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me make you sing. He takes her in his arms, again, begins to kiss her neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you love me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to love me. He stops kissing her, looks her in the eye. Then, another loud crow. Laughing, they fall into each other again. 53A   EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. GROUNDS. NIGHT. And we hear their laughter over the dark old house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valentin sits by himself on the porch, writes in his diar Down below, some of the disciples listen to peasants play music around a bonfire. A voice from the darkness. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not supposed to do this either. He locates the speaker by the glow of her lit cigarette. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Masha. You are not supposed to smoke at Telyatinki. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't look at me. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was difficult in front of the others. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it wasn't difficult in your bed... When it was only you and me in front of God. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I was conscious of God. Masha emerges from the shadows, but keeps her distance. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, I made you forget God? VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, only for a moment. You forgot your rules and remembered love. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You make it sound very simple. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is simple. What we did is what men and women do, have done, will continue doing. What could be more simple? We touched each other-- stayed close together. Something passed between us. Something real. That is a betrayal of what? Of nothing. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MASHA (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're afraid... All your ideas. What are you afraid of? VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I've hurt you, havenВґt

dialogues.speaker: I
dialogues.text: MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I feel a little sad, but it is not for me. It's for you. She disappears into the house. Valentin looks after her. 55   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. SOFYA'S BEDROOM. MORNING. The Countess wakes to find her bed empty. 56   EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. BACK TERRACE. DAY. She comes through the dining room to find Tolstoy on the back terrace. Wrapped in a blanket, he writes in his diar a cup of tea in front of him. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, my darling? Do you mind if I join you? Without looking up TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, my dear. He continues to write. She watches him for a long moment. She opens her diary and begins to write as well. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's quite insane, my darling. Everyone is making fun of you. He looks up. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? She continues to write. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even the muzhiks. I heard them laughing in the barn. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what? Sofya looks at him knowingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughing about what? SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to ruin last night. She sips her tea, goes back to her writing. A pause. He follows suit. After a moment... SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughing about the fact that you've developed a senile crush on a fat middle aged flatterer. Your passion for Chertkov has become a standing joke. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a great affection for Vladimir Grigorivich. Let them laugh if they find it amusing. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's not amusing, darling. It's sick. It's not normal. You hang on his every word. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a great deal in common. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have nothing in common. You are a genius. He's a sycophant and a pervert. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he understands what I'm trying to do? Because he tries to help me accomplish it? SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is using you. You just can't seem to see it. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is absolute nonsense. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That bold, obese, idiotic man. You treat him... He turns to her...his face red with anger and frustration TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's impossible for you not to distract me. Let me alone... for God's sake. You're like a spoiled child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rises, spits on the ground, goes into the house. Sofya follows. 57    INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. DINING ROOM. CONTINUOUS. Catching him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you love me, Lyovochka?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why would you betray me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because of the will?

dialogues.speaker: INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. ENTRY WAY/STAIRS/LANDING. DAY
dialogues.text: Tolstoy, taken aback, says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The new will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no new will. She stares at him in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no new will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does Chertkov have it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no new will. He walks up the stairs. She follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's why he's come back. You talk about it, you and your boyfriend. You plan for it. You have no heart for the people who really love you. You'd rather be seduced by charlatans and deluded by flatterers, all in the name of love....You can't even love your own children. You can't even love me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me where it is? TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no new will. 58   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. LIBRARY. CONTINUOUS. He goes to his desk, tries to ignore her. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, promise me there never will be. A moment's hesitation. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IВґve told you the truth. Now, let me work. Please, will you? He walks to his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tolstoy looks up from his work. Sofya stands in the doorway. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow, I'll go to the Station and lie down on the track. Tolstoy's wife becomes Anna Karenina herself! See how the papers will like that! As he goes, we hear. TOLSTOY (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is unbearable. You don't want a husband. You want a Greek chorus. Sofya is taken aback by his response. She walks out of th room.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ROAD TO TELYATINKI. DAY
dialogues.text: Four peasants pull a water cart down a rough country road We pan off to see Sofya in her droshky, resplendent in a white dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHERTKOV and SERGEYENKO look through a crack in the interior window. THEIR POV - the Countess on the sofa drinking a glass of tea. Valentin enters from the meeting room. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's here to question you about the new will. Chertkov nervous, tugs at his moustache. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does she know it even exists? VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She claims Leo Nikolayevich told her she could examine the draft. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is obviously not thinking clearly. And now we have to put up with her petty grasping. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't seem petty to me. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon? VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He`s her life. The work, in her mind, is theirs...together. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're her advocate? You've been taken in by her celebrity. I worried about this. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talking about their history -- - simply that. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should see her. Act as if nothing has happened. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing has happened. 63   INT. TELYATINKI. MEETING ROOM. DAY. The men enter the meeting room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofya Andreyevna, at last, you honour us with your visit. Valentin watches her match him smile for smile. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm happy to make you happy...always. She looks at him curiously. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your moustache is... Drooping, one side of it anyway. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) It's a problem of the wax. Sofya takes them in. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me get to the point. Vladimir Grigorivich, I don't wish to be your enemy. I'm delighted that my husband has a friend who understands and shares his ideals. All I want is what's reasonable - an opportunity to evaluate the new will. If you agree, I'm sure we can be friends. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're very kind. Sofya Andreyevna. But I can't help you. Not without specific instructions from your husband. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bulgakov) Leo Nikolayevich has agreed, hasn't he Val- CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No witness you produce will change my position. But I'll certainly talk to Leo Nikolayevich at the first opportunity. Sofya is livid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want us to be friends, too, Sofya. Leo Nikolayevich is the most valuable thing in the world, for both of us. We should endeavor to set things right between us. Give him peace. Let him work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valentin Fedorovich...are you coming back to the house with me? Valentin glances between them, searching for middle groun VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll escort the Countess home and be back in time for supper. Sergeyenko sneers. SERGEYENKO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Masha will be overjoyed. Valentin's nose twitches. He looks at the floor. SOFYA (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you been keeping something from me? How delightful. 64   EXT. ROAD TO TELYATINKI. DAY. They are back in the droshky, the return trip to Yasnaya Polyana. Valentin doesn't respond. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've become close friends, I think. Tell me everything, dear boy. I love a romance. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nothing, really. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young woman in your life is nothing? VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Masha is a friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lover?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A good friend. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sounds serious enough. Valentin looks away. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mean to annoy you. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You forget that I'm an experienced reader. I can read your face, every letter. It's beautifully clear. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you love her? Valentin looks at Sofya, tears in his eyes. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not something they'd understand, these so called disciples of my husband. They've never understood a word he's written. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do any of them know about love? 65   EXT. TELYATINKI COMPOUND. DAY. Masha carries two water buckets suspended from a pole across her shoulders. Arriving at a stream, she takes eac bucket and fills it. It's hot work. Pausing a moment, she kneels to splash water on her face. Another P.O.V. - someone watches her from the trees. As Masha wets a cloth, puts it around her neck. Suddenly someone grabs her from behind. She screams, wrestle her way free. She turns to see Valentin, flushed, smiling, excited. He steps toward her, kicks over one of the buckets. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, sorry, I'll... I didn't mean to scare you...Are you alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine...fine...Why did you...? VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came back as soon as I could. It was a strange day. Leo Nikolayevich,...I love to listen to him. I love nothing more... He moves closer to her. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But today I could hardly concentrate. He's very close to her, now. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I could think of was you. Masha shakes her head, moves away from him. Begins to gather the pole, to refill the spilled bucket. Stops her, turns her to him. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong? MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I've confused you. I've confused us both. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No. You didnВґt confuse me..I was stupid. I was afraid, but I'm not afraid anymore. Valentin wants to fight through the awkwardness. He tries to kiss her. She won't have it. She pulls away. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, Masha! MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you could help me a little. In silence, he gets the filled buckets balanced on the pole. Without another word, Masha starts toward the buildings. He doesn't know what to do. He's losing her. H shouts. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Masha... She turns

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before the other night...I'd committed the act of copulation many times in my heart. He has her attention now, as well as that of a number of the disciples who look up from their work in the yard. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think about you all the time. In my heart IВґve comitted the act of copulation many times. I just want to say...It was never like it was with you. Masha bursts out laughing. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll wait for you, then. As Valentin goes to catch her up, he sees Sergeyenko watching from outside the unfinished chicken coop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofya wakes up. She looks relaxed, then she sniffs, sniff again. Out of bed, she grabs a dressing gown. Opening her door, she spots Ivan in the hall. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ivan, who's wearing that awful perfume? Ivan a gesture indicating an elaborate moustache. She ste into the hall in time to see Tolstoy, Chertkov, Valentin and Sasha disappear into the library, ducks back into her room to avoid being seen

dialogues.speaker: INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. HALLWAY. DAY
dialogues.text: Sofya approaches the door, listens. She can make out only few words. "Mama cannot find out", Chertkov shushing her, whispers. We push in on Sofya's anxious face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chertkov, Sasha, Dushan, Valentin and Tolstoy sit in a little clump by his desk. Tolstoy his head in his hands, looks at the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate to say it but the Countess has become more and more dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not dangerous... She's concerned for the welfare of the family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tolstoy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we're concerned for the welfare of mankind. (to Bulgakov)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take this down. Valentin records the conversation in his diary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ItВґs a terrible thing you ask. I canВґt do it. 70    INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. SOFYA'S BEDROOM. DAY. Sofya, still in her dressing gown, climbs out her bedroom window onto a narrow ledge that runs along the second floor. 70A   EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. GROUNDS. DAY. Sofya stand on the window ledge high above the ground. begins to move toward the library balcony. 71    INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. LIBRARY. DAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been more than reasonable. She already controls the income from your property.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to him, papa. He has our best interests at heart. Tolstoy looks at Valentin, who looks at the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're speaking only of the rights to your words, your ideas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHERTKOV (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all love and respect, the Countess is too interested in making a profit from your work. 72   EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. SECOND STORY BALCONY. DAY. Sofya moves along the narrow ledge as if it's a perfectly normal activity.. Looking down, she sees a couple of gawkers watching her from the lawn. She shoos them away. 73   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. LIBRARY. DAY. Valentin turns his head. Did he hear something? TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's my wife. SheВґs part of me. We've been together now, so many years.... Chertkov drives the point home. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
