dialogues.text: But you're more than a husband and father. She must understand that. The best interests of the people are one with your own. You belong to them. Valentin glances up...and is shocked to see SOFYA LOOKING IN AT THE STUDY WINDOW. She disappears. 74   EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. SECOND STORY BALCONY. DAY. Sofya has reached the french doors. She can hear clearly now. TOLSTOY (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she won't. She'll never understand. HER P.O.V. a crowd of gawkers gather on the lawn below he One man sets up photographic equipment. She waves him awa turns back to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chertkov pushes his point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's unstable...I wonder if she isn't ill. DUSHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ItВґs sadly more than possible. SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know itВґs hard for you, papa. But we must be realistic. We pan to the french doors to see Sofya furious face as s listens to the betrayal. CHERTKOV (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you really think she's fit to control the final disposition of the will? We pan back to the conspirators. Before Tolstoy can respond, Sofya charges into the room. As she does, she steps on the hem of her long dressing gown and ends up sprawled on the floor. The conspirators just stare at her SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How dare you? SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're all plotting against me. In my own house, too. I bear you thirteen children. How can you betray me like this? (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone help me up. No one moves.   Tolstoy slumps in his chair. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give everything you've got to him, your fat little catamite. "What will it be, my dearest dear, my Vladimir Grigorivich? My wife's heart on a platter? Her kidneys? With salt? But of course, my dear Chertkov, whatever pleases you. The china. The estate. Permanent copyright on everything I've ever written? Anything for you, my love."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eye falls on Dushan, who very unfortunately, has chos to take this down in his diary. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me that. Give it to me, you little weasel. She grabs the offending volume. The struggle begins. DUSHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Countess Sofya- SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama, please... She rips the book away and after brandishing it above her head, throws it through the open doors with a guttural, rumbling growl. She turns on her tormentors. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now... TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbles) Can I not...Can I not have... His face is red, his body rigid with anger. SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll kill him, Mama. That's what you want, isn't it? You want him to die!" She helps him up, takes him to his bedroom. Valentin follows. She looks at Chertkov. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You! Don't think you deceive me for one little moment! I know exactly what you're doing. I want to see the will. It's my right, in the name of god. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you afraid of? SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You.   I'm afraid of you. Chertkov looks at her with undisguised disgust. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The press is bloodthirsty. Had I wished, I could've demolished you and your family. You make it easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell them anything you like. Go ahead. Ruin us. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have too much respect for Leo Nikolayevich. You're lucky. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't my husband see you for what you are? Chertkov's face is red. He starts to speak, stops. He wal to the door, then very deliberately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I had a wife like you, I would have blown my brains out long ago. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or gone to America. He leaves the room. Sofya sinks back to the floor, a flow wilting. She begins to weep. An Aria from Madame Butterfl comes over 78   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. DINING ROOM. NIGHT. From a record on the gramophone. The table is set for ten although no one is at dinner but Sofya Andreyevna and Valentin. He is visibly uncomfortable. An awkward silence VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you're feeling better. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like the opera?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took singing lessons for years. I thought about a career in music. The only thing I lacked, in the end, was talent. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about everything. She smiles. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This aria is very beautiful.. It is about a woman who is abandoned by the man who loves her...Everyone is very moved by that...in the opera. A long pause. The clink of soup spoons.   Tolstoy enters. He doesn't sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our life together has become intolerable. Stifling a sneeze, Valentin gets up to leave,tries to fle the inappropriateness of all this. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down, Valentin. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really, I'm expected at Telyatinki. She waves it off. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no. Enjoy your dinner. We've had a disagreement. No more than any other married couple. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't come for more recrimination. Despite good cause for alienation between us, I have never stopped loving you. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course... TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God knows you don't make it easy. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should it be easy? I'm the work of your life. You're the work of mine. Its what love is. Aside to Valentin. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything with him is hysterics VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should go. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down. (beat) So, this is what love is.   Does that surprise you, boy? They both look at him VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it might be quieter, but-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sneezes violently. TOLSTOY/SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God bless you Tolstoy turns to Sofya. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right, though. If we cannot live a decent, quiet life, if I cannot work, if I cannot find some peace, I shall simply go away. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go? Where? TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to Chertkov, but I shall go. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go where? TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dushan says you're killing me. Sofya rises up in cold rage. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then go! Go! Anywhere you please! She smashes a plate on the table to punctuate it and another and another. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate you. I hate what you've become. She picks up another plate, lets it fall. Now, she acts a if she's choking or gasping for breath. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Countess...Are you alright? She fights with her collar, rips open the front of her dress. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts)

dialogues.speaker: DUSHAN
dialogues.text: SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll destroy me. Dushan runs into the room. Sofya continues to tear at her clothes, stops, begins to pant, then falls to the floor i a faint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she alright? Tolstoy tries to answer, but is overcome by a coughing fi Dushan starts toward him but Tolstoy waves him in the direction of Sofya. He kneels beside her. DUSHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofya! Open your eyes. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My back. My back... I'm hurting. DUSHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're lying on a fork. Sit up and you'll improve markedly...Valentin, help to get her upstairs, would you? Valentin helps Sofya to her feet. Dushan gets up himself and walks to Tolstoy. DUSHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's alright. I'm more concerned for you... We should all go to bed before something else happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valentin sits at the bonfire, with other disciples. After while he walks towards the house. 81   INT. TELYATINKI. KITCHEN. NIGHT. It's late. The house is quiet. Valentin walks into the kitchen to see Masha washing the dishes. Exhausted, he sits, stares at the floor. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was terrible there today... between them. They loved each other so much, but you see what it becomes. She stays at the sink, says nothing. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Masha, whatВґs the matter? She speaks without turning to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going back to Moscow. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? He gets up, goes to her. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chertkov spoke with me this afternoon. He says I could be more useful there...which means... Valentin shakes his head. His lip trembles. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is him punishing us, punishing me for befriending Sofya Andreyevna. For not... This is Chertkov. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've both disappointed him. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care. You can't go away. I'll talk to him. I'll make him change his mind. iВґm going to make you stay. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I want to go. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm leaving the movement. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You canВґt leave Tolstoy. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not. Look, when I read his Confession, it moved me, Valya. He was searching for freedom. Freedom from anger. Freedom from attachment. Freedom from all the superstition and nonsense of the church. It moved me so much. I thought that's what it would be about. Isn't that what it's about? Freedom and love? But they mix it all up. Masha reaches out and puts her arms around him. Her head falls against his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come with me. Please. Bulgakov doesn't know what to say. The silence gets more awkward as it gets longer. Slowly, she disengages herself from him,looks him in the eye. She nods. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to my room. As she starts away. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't leave me, Masha... I need you. She turns back for a moment. MASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you do...I know. Then she's gone. 82   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. SOFYA'S BEDROOM/HALLWAY. DAY. Sofya in her bed. A team of doctors hover over her. One o them peers into her eyes with a sextant-like instrument. We move into the hall to find DR. ROSSOLIMO, an expert in mental illness, conferring in the hall with Tolstoy and Dushan. ROSSOLIMO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe the Countess suffers from a mental degeneracy, paranoic and hysterical, chiefly the former.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. The doctor walks back into the bedroom. Tolstoy red in th face, walks away down the hall. Dushan catches him. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you bring him here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's an old friend, you know, from Rome. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And astoundingly stupid in the way of all scientists. Dushan is wounded by his uncharacteristic lack of generosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, my friend, but this is all very upsetting to me. DUSHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Tolstoy sits on a small staircase at the end of the hall. Bulgakov is already there on the step above him. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take them downstairs. Thank them for me. Offer them a drink. DUSHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be alright? TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valentin Fedorovich will stay with me, won't you, boy Valentin nods. Dushan goes to collect the doctors. MOMENTS LATER-Tolstoy goes to Sofya's bed. He takes her hand. She looks at him with all the love of a new bride. Tears come to his eyes. He kisses her hand. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya...your...your...I canВґt remember now...Yo, what did I say? What did you mean? TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You rest now. Valentin watches from the doorway as Tolstoy leaves the bedside and walks out. 83   EXT. ZASYEKA WOODS. DAY. It is an autumn afternoon. Valentin and Tolstoy pick thei way through the thick undergrowth. As they come into a clearing. Valentin is surprised to se a portable table and several chairs set up like lawyers office in the middle of the wood. Sergeyenko fiddles with piece of paper on the desk. Chertkov comes toward them. Tolstoy stops his horse. He turns to Valentin with tears his eyes. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, I no longer feel I have a choice in the matter. She isn't... He rides forward toward the approaching Chertkov.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Leo Nikolayevich. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it? They help Tolstoy dismount. They lead him to a nearby stu and place the writing board before him. Sergeyenko hands document to Chertkov who lays it on the board. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This will insure that the complete works will live in the public domain. SERGEYENKO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monumentous. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your work is the birthright of the Russian people. Now, they possess it forever. Tolstoy looks up at them. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes? TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a pen. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. Chertkov looks at Sergeyenko who swallows hard. No pen. SERGEYENKO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I...uh... CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Sergeyenko moves close to Chertkov, close enough to whisper. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a secretary.       How can you not have a pen? Sergeyenko points at Valentin. SERGEYENKO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a secretary, too.      Ask him. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valentin Fedorovich, do you have a pen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valentin hesitates for a moment, looks at Tolstoy, seated on the stump, staring into the middle distance. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. Valentin fetches it from his satchel. Pen in hand, Tolstoy hovers over the document. A long moment. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you alright? TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like a conspirator. Sergeyenko laughs. Chertkov glares at him. It's beyond awkward. Valentin looks to the sky, sees the crows circling again. Without further hesitation, Tolstoy picks up the pen and signs the document. Then he moves away from the group. Valentin watches him. 84   EXT. ZASYEKA WOODS. DAY. Valentin and Tolstoy water their horses at a stream. Tolstoy seems weary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we should get back. It'll be dark soon. May I ask you something that has nothing to do with work? TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, my dear. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you love your wife? TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: " Your youth and your desire for happiness reminds me cruelly of my age and the impossibility of happiness for me." When I was courting Sofya, she was so young and pure, it seemed impossible that I'd ever have her. I didn't want to tell her how I felt and I wanted to tell her nothing else. So I wrote down a string of letters and asked her if she could decipher them. She looked completely confused, thinking it was a game or...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tolstoy looks into the middle distance, remembering his love. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave her one clue. The first two Y's, I said, stand for "your youth" and then the most miraculous thing happened. She simply spoke the phrase, my phrase... Tolstoy looks at Valentin as if the boy might offer some explanation of the miraculous. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...as if she had read my mind. In that moment, we both knew we would always be together. For those first years, we were incredibly happy, terrifyingly happy. His old eyes are wet. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now this. Tolstoy reaches into his boot, extracts his SECRET DIARY. He takes a pen from his shirt, begins to write. Valentin amazed. HE HAD A PEN ALL THE TIME. 85   INT. TELYATINKI. MEETING ROOM. NIGHT. Valentin exhausted, sits at the long table.   Chertkov appears at his office door. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you again, Valentin Fedorovich, for your forethought. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a secretary, after all. Chertkov let's it go. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I had thought for a time to suggest that Leo Nikolayevich look for someone else. But...he said no. He said "He reminds me of myself when I was young." He goes. After a moment, Valentin gets up and goes to the study door. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm leaving Telyatinki.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am going to Moscow. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is leading you around the nose. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, you say the movement's about love- CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... The love he tells us to practice, the love of the Gospels. Why do I have to explain this? Perfect love. Eternal love. The love that binds mankind together. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I've never met mankind, only men and women, imperfect men, imperfect women. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo Nikolayevich also teaches us love can not be weakminded. Go. You won't be missed ...a naive sentimentalist Valentin looks at him for a long moment, then bursts out laughing, walks away CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you laughing? You think I'm ridiculous. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm laughing because I didn't sneeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tolstoy has fallen asleep at his desk, his SECRET DIARY open before him. Sofya enters without knocking. He bolts groggily, tries to hide the little book. Sofya, meanwhile holds up the letter in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyovochka? Prozeveskeny wants to purchase the rights to your work after your death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I shall try and die as soon as is convenient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be silly. They've offered one million rubles. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you not be pleased?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't write for publishers. I write for people. He gets up from his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valentin's in the library.    He's asked to speak to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Splendid...while your wretched family is left to starve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see anyone starving in this house. On the contrary, our privilege revolts me. He goes.   She calls after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're always first to the trough...always have been. Sofya sinks into his chair. On the desk is the photograph of herself and Tolstoy that we saw her hang on the wall i the early part of the film. She looks at the wall. There in it's place is the offending photograph of CHERTKOV tha she had removed earlier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can fix that. But as she picks up the photo of her an her husband, she notices A SMALL VOLUME, THE SECRET DIARY lying under it. She begins to read. 90   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. LIBRARY. DAY. Valentin waits on the sofa.   Tolstoy walks in, goes to h TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, dear boy? You look unhappy. What do you want to say? But before Valentin can respond A GUNSHOT RINGS OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofya sits in a chair, firing shot after shot at the photograph of Chertkov. Tolstoy and Valentin enter. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofya, what are you doing? She turns toward him, waves the gun in his direction. Valentin ducks against the wall. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could you do this to me? TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hurt me again and again. You take little pieces of me until I become nothing. I don't know who I am anymore. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I read your diary. I know what you've done. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You behave like this, I have no choice. Now give me the gun. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Give me the gun! TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it to me, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofya throws the gun at her husband. She runs out of the room. We see the shattered photograph of Chertkov. After a moment, Tolstoy into his chair.   Valentin watche him in silence. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like you to stay here tonight. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. With that, the old man gets up and leaves the room, leavi Valentin in the wreckage of his world. 93   EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. GROUNDS. NIGHT. The wind blows the trees around the old house.   We see a lighted lamp move up the stairs. 94   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. LIBRARY. NIGHT. Valentin in his makeshift bed. SASHA (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valentin. Valentin. He is immediately awake. Sasha, lamp in hand, crouches beside him. SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get up. He's leaving. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HeВґs leaving.

dialogues.speaker: INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. TOLSTOY'S BEDROOM/STUDY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Bags are being prepared. Sasha is packing clothes. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Essentials only. Nothing that isn't absolutely necessary. Valentin struggles to close a case full of books and papers. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please...we must hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where will you go? No one responds. Dushan comes to Tolstoy, sits down and begins the ritual taking of the pulse. Meanwhile, Sasha wraps a heavy fur coat around his shoulders. She smiles a him. SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely essential.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lantern, I think. It's very dark tonight. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the apparatus for giving an enema. 96   EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. GROUNDS. NIGHT. The horses are hitched to the droshky, the bags are up on the back. SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's ready. Dushan climbs into the carriage. Tolstoy turns abruptly a walks back toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa...? DUSHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's changed his mind. He's going back to the house. They watch as Tolstoy kneels on the wet grass, bending lo to rub his hands against the earth. After a moment, Valentin goes to him, kneels next to him. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to go back? TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was a boy, my brother Nikolai once brought me to a place when I was a boy. He told me he'd found a green stick with some words on it... the secret to happiness for all men everywhere. He hid it in the ground. I looked for it very often. I've looked for it all these years. I really believed I would find it here...but I never did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tolstoy looks at him. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never did...but this life is behind me now. He kisses the ground of his beloved home, gets up and the walk back to the droshky. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help me up, will you? As they go, he hands Valentin an envelope. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give this to Sofya. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will. They reach the carriage. Sasha embraces him, kisses him over and over. SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be well. Be well. TOLSTOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't cry. I'll send for you when I can. They help him up onto the droshky and the carriage starts slowly away from the old house.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. GROUNDS. MORNING
dialogues.text: Out in front of the house, an old peasant woman pulls the feathers off a chicken. Over her impassive face, we hear deep, heavy sobs. 98   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. SITTING ROOM. DAY. Sofya is in a rage. Sasha sits nearby. SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm simply telling you what happened. He's gone. I have no idea where. Nobody does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a liar. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liar! Sasha won't rise to the bait. Valentin comes into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, he's gone. (to Bulgakov)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For good. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so, yes. There is a pause. Sofya suddenly smiles, becomes solicitous. SOFY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling Sasha, where is your father? I know you know. Please, please. Don't play games with me. Now itВґs not the moment. SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honestly, I have no idea. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: DON'T PLAY GAMES WITH ME.
dialogues.text: VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have this for you. It is a letter. She grabs it, as if it is something that might feed a terrible hunger at the center of her. Moving into a corner, she tears it open and begins to read. They both watch Sofya's passion. Her face quivers, the muscles in her neck stand out. Her shoulders begin to shake. Crumbling the paper in her hand, she twists her head and screams. Then, gathering up her dress, she runs out the door. Sasha move immediately to the window. From her P.O.V., we see Sofya streaking across the lawn. They look at each other

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pond! They run out. 99   EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. GROUNDS. DAY. Sofya sprints away from the house and into the trees. A couple of servants join the chase, Ivan and VANYA, a fat manservant. Valentin, head of the group, sees Sofya move out of the birches. She's heading straight to the pond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sasha suddenly steams past him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama, Mama! Stop. Not this. Hurry! Hurry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Countess!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. POND. DAY
dialogues.text: Sofya has reached the bathhouse. Peasant women watch her they do their wash. She glances back her pursuers, races on. Tiring now, she goes to her knees. She crawls along the jetty toward the water. At the edge of the jetty, she falls on her back then turns over, most ungracefully, and rolls off sideways into the pond. HIGH ANGLE. Sofya sinks into the black water. The sound o her rescuers fades away and is replaced by Tolstoy's voic reading the farewell note she still clutches in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My position in the house has become intolerable. What I'm doing now is what people have commonly done - leave their worldly life behind to spend their last days in peace and solitude. SLOW MOTION She floats, strangely relaxed, beneath the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg you to forgive me for everything I've done to you, just as I forgive you with all my soul for everything you've done to me. The silence is suddenly ripped apart by the rescuers. Sas and Valentin jumping into the pond. Sasha, barely able to swim herself, thrashes in the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sasha, go back to the jetty. Here, let me help you. He offers his arm, using it to push her to safety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! She's drowning.     Help her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will. I will. Stay here. With that, he pushes away from the dock and makes a sharp plunge under the water. Sasha watches, waits...and after a long moment Valentin surfaces pulling Sofya with him. On the dock, the servants and Sasha help him to get her heavy body , water soaked dress, back onto the bank. She looks terrible. Her tongue lolling out, water drizzli from her open mouth. Sasha is overcome. SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's dead. My mother. She's dead. Ivan takes action. He rolls her on to her stomach, works expel water from her lungs. This goes on for an agonizing length of time. Valentin looks to the sky... dull and gra Then a sound, coughing sputtering. She is alive. Sasha, Valentin, and the servants help up. SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me take you to the house, mother. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me die. Please. Why would you rob me of that? SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go to the house. Sofya is suddenly clear, almost calm. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ivan, go to the station. Find out which train the master took. Ivan looks at Sasha for approval. SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see no harm in it. Let's get her to bed. Valentin nods. Ivan appears beside him. IVAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life returns to torture her for awhile. He laughs out loud,then walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sasha walks into dining room. Valentin pours them tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's exhausted herself. She's slept for nearly four hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad she can sleep. The pain subsides a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The noise subsides a little. They smile at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, a little. Ivan comes down the stairs. He stops in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A message, miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, for your father. From the Countess, miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's allowed to send a note to my father. I just don't know where to tell her to send it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's addressed it to train number 9. That's the train the master took. The station master told me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you giving it to me? She is allowed to send my father a note! Ivan steps forward and hands her the note to inspect. Sas can't help but laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She never gives up. (reading the note)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Dearest papa. Return at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SASHA (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sasha." She signed it with my name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ingenious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obvious. She pockets the note. Ivan continues to stand there. Sash looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gave me this as well...the stationmaster. A note for you. Sasha opens it, reads. She looks up, flushed with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's with my aunt.      At the Shamardino. Sasha runs out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. YASNAYA POLYANA. GROUNDS. DAY
dialogues.text: Sasha, on horse back, rides up and by the camera and away down the alley of trees that lead away from the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've all gone 103   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. LIBRARY. DAY. Sitting at his desk, Valentin looks up to see Sofya standing in the doorway. She looks exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here. She walks to his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're writing to your girl. That's lovely. Sofya touches his shoulder with real affection, then walk across the room to her husband's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if she's my girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you believe you'll see her again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I very much hope so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Refuse to believe in the end of love. Do all you can to prevent it... Sofya picks up a photograph of the two of them, examines it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you know where he is, Valentin. Valentin hesitates. She walks back to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't ask you to betray his trust...but I need you to go to him. I do. I have to see him. I have to talk to him. I won't make a scene. Promise him that. I must see him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COUNTRYSIDE. DAWN
dialogues.text: Clouds of steam against the white sky. A great black trai travels through the bleak world 109    INT. THIRD CLASS CARRIAGE. DAY. Tolstoy rests on the hard bench of the third class carria he always insists on. He writes on his lapboard. We pan t an adjacent bench to find VALENTIN, now with them. He and Sasha have a map spread out in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right, you know, to go. She will be right behind us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IВґve told you she has promised she wouldnВґt make any problems. But besides, where are we going? Tolstoy has overheard them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't need a plan, my dears, we'll simply go Dushan appears with several newspapers.   As he hands the the papers, he reads the HEADLINES.

dialogues.speaker: YASNAYA POLYANA TAKES FLIGHT
dialogues.text: Tolstoy looks up from the papers, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess our little secret is out.

dialogues.speaker: INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. SITTING ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Sofya sits surrounded by the papers. Andrey appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a reporter outside from the Russian World.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him we've received an apologetic letter from your father..very embarrassed. We expect him back any day...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's a lie, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that's a lie.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COUNTRYSIDE. DAY
dialogues.text: The huge iron wheels grind on.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THIRD CLASS TRAIN CARRIAGE. DAY
dialogues.text: Tolstoy sleeps. People still crowd around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please move back. Please let him breath. Please give him some room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Valentin) He canВґt breath. Valentin, please. (to Dushan)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The smoke is too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Stay back. Tolstoy stirs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's alright. Everything's fine. He reaches out to touch Tolstoy's forehead. He goes pale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me take your temperature. The old man lifts his shirt, takes the thermometer under his arm. Dushan reaches for his wrist. Valentin and Sasha look at each other, wait for the vital signs. He takes th thermometer from Tolstoy, reads it. He's clearly shaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good old Dushan,...you needn't worry. Remember, you are my doctor, not my angel. Whatever happens, it's not your fault... I'm feeling much better now. I just need to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, good. Yes. He drifts off again, Dushan stares at the thermometer. Hi eyes fill with tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He will be fine.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ASTAPOVO. PLATFORM. DAY
dialogues.text: The train pulls into a small, dusty station, ASTAPOVO. Valentin and Dushan support, help him off the train.   Sa looks at the sad, empty platform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've come to the end of the world. 115   EXT. ASTAPOVO. PLATFORM. DAY. Dushan and Tolstoy sit on a bench on the platform. Sasha and Valentin appear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stationmaster says we may have his house for as long as we need it. There are no inns nearby, so we're lucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very lucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. They help Tolstoy up. A little bearded man, the station master, waits to escort them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be comfortable here, papa. The rest of us...we'll find cots or sleep in the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then we'll be on our way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valentin approaches the operator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, hello? Could you send a cable for me?

dialogues.speaker: INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. LIBRARY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A message comes over the cable machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tolstoy ill at Astapovo. Temperature high. Send it to Sofya Andreyevna, Yasnaya Polyana. 120   INT. YASNAYA POLYANA. SITTING ROOM. NIGHT. Sofya paces. Andrey lolls on the couch reading the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must leave at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll make inquiries in the morning, mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll rent a train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'll cost a fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say irrelevant things, Andrey. It's unbecoming. Contact someone. I'll go and pack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rent a train? God! 121   EXT. ASTAPOVO. PLATFORM. DAY. Press and various hangers on have begun to arrive at Astapovo. Outside the station master's house, Dushan give an update, temperature, pulse. Valentin emerges from the telegraph office, telegrams and cables in his hands. A long passenger train pulls in from the north. There's general commotion at the new arrival. "The Countess." "Is it the Countess?"... More press, a cinematographer lugging his gear and CHERTKOV. He spots Valentin. There is no greeting, no embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bulgakov! Where is he?    Take me to him. As they make their way across the tracks, Chertkov can barely contain his glee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He left...astonishing...He actually, finally left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wasn't well enough to travel. It's very cold. Chertkov doesn't hear, He's basking in his victory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a triumph for the movement. 122   INT. ASTAPOVO. STATIONMASTER'S HOUSE. DAY. Valentin leads Chertkov through the door. Chertkov stops short, whispers

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks so small. Now, Tolstoy sees him, wakes up, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's(hic)you. The men embrace. Tears roll down the both men's cheeks. Tolstoy continues to hiccup throughout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear friend, waht is all of this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I needed (hic) to see you. Thank you. We have so much (hic) to do. (hic) IВґm sorry. Damn hic ups. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you seen Sofya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've made a point not to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know when (hic) she'll come. But she'll come (hic). I know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we'll be ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready for what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chertkov doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, but it's time for your enema.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't apologize, my friend. Your enemas(hic)have become the news of the world. (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, all of you, help turn me over. 123   INT. ASTAPOVO. STATIONMASTER'S HOUSE. NIGHT. Everyone is asleep. Valentin keeps a vigil at Tolstoy's bedside. His rest is fitful, his breathing ragged. Valent stands and walks out. 124   INT. ASTAPOVO. TELEGRAPH OFFICE. NIGHT. Valentin approaches the little window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to send another cable. The man nods, readies his pencil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At Astapovo. Stop. Tolstoy Ill. Stop. Heart breaking. Stop. Please Come.... That's it. The man looks to him for an address.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It goes to Masha...to Maria Filipovna Melinov, Moscow. Thank you. 125   EXT. ASTAPOVO. PLATFORM. DAY. The media circus is in town. There are snack bars and hut an army camp with typewriters instead of guns. Several ne cameras are set up near the stationmaster's house. Tents have been erected as make shift shelters and offices. Reporters struggle to get into the telegraph office. Word goes around something big is happening. At the platform, we see the highly polished private train pull in. The Countess has arrived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOFYA APPEARS in her handsome traveling clothes. An unctuous little orthodox priest follows her out of the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the Count should have a change of heart...if in the last moment he chooses to confess, mother church is there to embrace him with open arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see what I can do, father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves with purpose across the tracks and through the throng Reporters pelt her with questions. 126   INT. ASTAPOVO. STATIONMASTER'S HOUSE. DAY. Chertkov, Sasha and Valentin watch through the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's coming this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chertkov starts to put on his coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not before she stops to tell them lies, catalogue my atrocities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me speak to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He heads toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ASTAPOVO. PLATFORM. DAY
dialogues.text: Sofya has reached the edge of the platform where DUSHAN gives his medical update, temperature and pulse, to the press. She pulls Dushan aside. Reporters surround them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to see my husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I'll...uhm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to see him. Now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dushan is terrified. Valentin arrives at the platform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Countess!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valentin...Will you help me?    I have to see him. Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. But I'm not certain if itВґs the best time, Countess. She starts toward the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is.   It's the right time for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofya Andreyevna... (to the crowd) Stay back, stay back.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ASTAPOVO. STATIONMASTER'S HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: As Valentin arrives outside the door, he see Sofya physically recoil. She is confronted by Chertkov and Sash blocking the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to see my husband. Members of the press, crowd `round trying to listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's too weak now, mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he's not too weak to see you. Not too weak to see that... She gestures in Chertkov's direction. The passion attract more onlookers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you really want to do this here? She does her best to ignore him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am the leper outside the gate, while he sleeps with the devil himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vladimir Gregorovich is here because father asked him to be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This stops Sofya for a moment. She looks to Valentin. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that true? Valentin nods.   She tries another tack. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you told him I nearly drowned in the pond? SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We didn't have to. It was in all the papers. Valentin is very aware of the publicness of it all. VALENTIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me take you back. But she plows on. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he say? SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That if you killed yourself, he'd be upset. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd be upset? SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horribly upset...but he could not have acted other than he did. Sofya begins to sob. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to see him. (beat) He's not your husband.   He's my husband. SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're unbearable. Sasha goes back toward the door. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you are a stone-hearted bitch of a daughter. Sasha disappears back inside. Sofya screams after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lost five children. Why couldn't one of them have been you? Chertkov watches, makes little attempt to conceal his pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you finished? A pause. Sofya is suddenly aware of the crowd around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valentin, will you take me back? Valentin nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. Sofya takes his arm, starts back across the platform. Shaken, she tries her best to maintain her dignity as she walks through the crowd. She leans against Valentin, whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've behaved badly, haven't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Countess, Don't worry. Not at all. Around her, journalists ask questions, photographers call out "Turn to us, Countess." "Show us your eyes."

dialogues.speaker: INT. ASTAPOVO. PRIVATE TRAIN. DAWN.
dialogues.text: Valentin, in his wrinkled suit, is asleep in a chair. He wakes to see Sofya stretched out on the sofa. He watches her. She doesn't stir. After a moment, he goes out.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ASTAPOVO. PLATFORM. DAY
dialogues.text: Valentin emerges from the telegraph office. He walks alon the platform, a stack of letter and telegrams in his hand A few reporters type their early morning dispatches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valentin comes into the room, acknowledges Chertkov who sits at his makeshift desk going through letters and cables. He goes to the bedside, stops next to Dushan. Silence, interrupted only by Tolstoy's incessant hiccups. Valentin notices Dushan is on the verge of tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? Dushan, whatВґs wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to him. I'm supposed to be a doctor, for God's sake. Weak, feverish, Tolstoy sits up in bed.   Sasha moves to help him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofya!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? What is it? Valentin goes to Tolstoy. He's in a kind of panic. Chertk comes into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's come, hasn't she? She`s here. He points to the corner.   But it is nothing, a gray shap thrown by a coat rack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're imagining things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true, Leo Nikolayevich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sasha...where's your mother? Tolstoy's eyes fill with tears. Valentin looks to Sasha. She looks from him to Chertkov.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she wanted to see me I couldn't refuse her. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she going to come here? All eyes are on Sasha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so...I don't know, Papa. There's no way to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To what? Will she waiver?    A long, agonizing beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's at home. I'm sure of it. Valentin looks at the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Papa. Tolstoy nods, pats Sasha's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very beautiful isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. He leans back against the pillow and drifts again. Sasha gets up and goes outside. After a moment, Valentin follows.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ASTAPOVO. STATION MASTER'S HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: Valentin sees her leaning against the wall.   She's in pa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said to me once..."you're like your mother. You're so full of anger." She turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it's terrible...but who will protect him? I don't want him to die. Valentin touches her face, goes back inside and into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Chertkov has made a makeshift office. He pores through the cables, letters and telegrams that litter the station master's dining table. He holds one up for Valentin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind thoughts from George Bernard Shaw. Valentin walks to the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lied to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep your voice down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants to see her.    You heard him say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What exactly do you think she will bring him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I donВґt know, theyВґve been married for 48 years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IВґll tell you what sheВґll bring...Vanity, fuss and noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She promised me-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Promised you what? YouВґve seen her at close quarters, boy. You think sheВґs capable of restraining herself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have a whole life togehter. Why do you have to deny that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a victim of her romantic nonsense. You seem to forget she wants to destroy everything we do. She travels with that unctious little priest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep the priest away-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These people are vultures. They send in at the last moment and welcome him back to the church. That's their fantasy. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A death bed recantation. Do you have any idea the damage it would do? Everything he's dreamed of, everything we've worked for will be gone. A simple noble death is what we want. It is what he wants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you want an icon. You want to take photographs and give out postcards..You want people to kneel in front of an image youВґve created. But he doesnВґt wanted that. He never wanted that, and it will give him no peace. (beat) He wants to see her...let her come. They see Sasha looking from the door.   She turns and clo it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will do everything in my power to prevent that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God. You exhaust me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to think you were just naive, Valentin, maybe a little stupid.   I see now you're more dangerous than she is. He turns back at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me one thing. That image you want to create, just looks like you, doesnВґt it? Valentin leaves the room. 137   EXT. ASTAPOVO. PLATFORM. NIGHT. The circus sleeps. Valentin sits on a bench outside the station master's house. The tents erected by the press glow like lanterns in the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some people lie on the hard platform. He looks across the tracks at Sofya's private car. A single light burns in th window 138   INT. ASTAPOVO. PRIVATE TRAIN CARRIAGE. NIGHT. Sofya keeps her solitary vigil. The priest has fallen asleep sitting up. She finishes her prayers, gets up, looks across at the lonely cottage. She can make out Valentin's figure on the platform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dushan appears in the doorway. Solemn, he gestures for hi to come inside. Valentin stands. 140   INT. ASTAPOVO. PRIVATE TRAIN CARRIAGE. NIGHT. Sofya watches the two figures disappear inside. 141   INT. ASTAPOVO. STATIONMASTER'S HOUSE. NIGHT. Valentin sees Chertkov standing near the bed. Dushan returns to the chair next to Tolstoy. His cheeks are damp his breathing irregular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can't be right.    His fever is down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His pulse, you see... Dushan begins to cry. Suddenly, Tolstoy becomes lucid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofya...my dear Sofya. So much has (hic) fallen to her. Everyone moves nearer the bed. Tolstoy looks at Valentin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's going to look after her? (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone needs to look after her. There is a long pause. Sasha looks at Valentin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I call her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it(hic). The end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seems to smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to see her, papa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sasha, Sasha.. It's(hic)nothing...Nothing. He falls onto his pillow, asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's almost over. Sasha looks at him, shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do this anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wonВґt know who she is anyway. 142   INT. ASTAPOVO. TRAIN CARRIAGE. NIGHT. Everyone sleeps but Sofya. There is a knock on the door. Sofya opens it. It is Sasha. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has he asked for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to come.    Take a coat. It's cold. 143   EXT. ASTAPOVO. STATIONMASTER'S HOUSE. NIGHT. Sofya and Sasha walk to the door. The reporter calls out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Countess...Countess...Do you have any information? Countess...Is he dying? Is he dead? Sasha takes her mother's hand. 144   INT. ASTAPOVO. STATIONMASTER'S HOUSE. NIGHT. She steps into the room. For a moment, she seems overwhelmed at the sight of him. She looks at Valentin, w nods at her as if to say go on. Sofya walks past Chertkov without acknowledging him. Dushan lets go his hold of Tolstoy's wrist and gets out of the chair, out of her way She approaches her sleeping, husband, the love of her lif her cross, her everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyovochka! There is no response.    She throws her arms around him. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please forgive me, my darling! SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother... SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a fool.. I'm a selfish woman. But I love you. Please believe me. Please understand me. Please forgive me for all my weakness and badness. Please! Please! Love me! SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother! Sasha takes her hand, whispers. SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Control yourself. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was I shouting? SASHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to control yourself. Sofya looks around and sits back. Strangely, she does control herself. She becomes very still. She takes her husband's hand, begins quietly to speak to him. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't speak, but I hear you. She carries on two sides of an impossible conversation. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Do you love me, Lyovochka." (beat) "Never stopped, my little bird." (beat) "And you will never stop" (beat) "Never." (beat) "Nor ever leave me again." (beat) "Never, ever again. (beat) "Good...good... let's go home"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits very still holding her husband's hand. Then, it seems she feels the slightest of movements, the slightest squeeze of her hand. She looks down to see Tolstoy open h eyes. He looks at her for a moment, the hint of a smile, then closes his eyes again. Valentin sees it, glances at Sasha.   Then, he begins to fight for breath. DUSHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First cessation. A general sense of panic at the proximity of death. Tolst fights for a last breath. DUSHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second cessation. Sofya whispers quietly to her dying husband. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please forgive me if I cry a little now. Tolstoy continues to struggle, then silence, silence. Sasha starts to sob. Sofya reaches out to her daughter. Sasha comes to her mother who holds her. She feels someone next to her.   She looks up. It's Chertkov. CHERTKOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sorry, Sofya Andreyevna. The most unlikely thing, she pats his hand. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's alright. What happens from now on... it will never really matter. Not really. Everything's finished. Chertkov sits beside them. She turns to Dushan. SOFYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dushan, could you tell them your great friend is gone? DUSHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. He nods, walk out into the dawn light to tell the world L Tolstoy is dead.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ASTAPOVO. PLATFORM. DAY
dialogues.text: A sizeable crowd has assembled, the usual reporters, photographers, cinematographers, but students, too, and soldiers, factory workers, housewives. Dushan faces the crowd. Quiet. Quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At ten minutes after six in the morning, a great soul passed from our world. Leo Nikoleyevich Tolstoy is dead. As Dushan finishes his tribute, a single voice begins to sing the old Russian hymn, Eternal Memory. Gradually, mor and more of the crowd picks it up. Valentin begins to sin His eyes run over the crowd of mourners. Then, something stops the flow of his gaze. His eyes fill with tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Masha... Masha. She walks slowly toward him out of the crowd. He goes to her, takes her in a long embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Masha...Masha...I'm so sorry he's gone. HeВґs gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes. I know, but I came for you, Valya. I came for you, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you. I do. I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, hold me. Hold me. Hold me. The song, the voices swell around them.   They hold each other like they will never let go. 146   EXT. ASTAPOVO. PLATFORM. DAY. A black draped funeral train waits in the station. Many mourners are congregated on the platform. Chertkov comes out of the little house, followed by Andrey, Valentin and Dushan carrying Tolstoy's coffin to the train. Sofya appears with Sasha, who escorts her through the crowd. The Orthodox priest approaches .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a daughter of the church, I'm sure you wouldn't object to my saying a few words at the funeral. Sofya stares at him for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My husband needs no justification. Besides, itВґs been enough talking as it is. Thank you, father. She climbs onto the train. 147   INT. ASTAPOVO. PRIVATE CARRIAGE. DAY. Sofya settles into the comfort of the private car. She si next to Sasha. Andrey and Dushan are near her. There's a noise from outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Countess...Countess. She looks out. Below the train window, Valentin and Masha stand hand in hand. She gets up and opens the window. 148   EXT. ASTAPOVO. PLATFORM. DAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Countess. This may not be the time, but- Sofya smiles

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valentin... and who's this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Masha...this is Masha. Sofya nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is your girl. Good. Good. Is there anything I can do for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. Not at all. I just wanted to say good bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...Good bye, good bye.     God bless you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God bless you, too.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ASTAPOVO. PRIVATE TRAIN. DAY
dialogues.text: Sofya sits back down with Sasha. They hold hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm ready to go now. (to Andrey)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why arenВґt we moving? Can't someone make it move? But at that moment, the train begins to move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! 150   EXT. ASTAPOVO. PLATFORM. DAY. Sofya looks out the window, sees the people lined up alon the rail, mourn her loss. As she looks away, we see the people reflected in the glass, some of them kneel, some o them remove their hats. Valentin watches the train pull away. He holds Masha to him. As the train   moves slowly through the corridor of mourn some of them   fall in and walk behind it. The camera tra up and up as   the train travels north taking Sofya and h husband back   to Yasnaya Polyana.
